results.title: How animal life begins
results.brief_description: Portrays the ovulation, fertilization and early development of the mammalian egg. Scenes of spermatizoa attacking the ovum, and time-lapse micro-photographs of cell division in the fertilized egg.

results.title: How about you? (TEFC)
results.brief_description: A sex educational film which uses a factual but informal style. Discusses social attitudes towards sexuality and shows the effectiveness of a variety of contraceptive methods (somewhat out of date!). It also discusses women’s issues and the freedom of women to own and control their own body. Please note this film was made in 1972 and pre-dates AIDS.

results.title: How about a break; You can do it
results.creator_credit: Debby Kingsland, Suzanne Baker and Film Australia
results.brief_description: Two short films in one. The first shows the frustration’s faced by an ‘average’ housewife, the second, the benefits of engaging in recreational activities outside the home. Cast includes Max Cullen, Julie Dawson, Kate Whiteley, Beth Whiteley.

results.title: How a cheque book works
results.creator_credit: Raymond Leach, Andrew J. Helgeson, Austral Pacific Productions and National Bank of Australia
results.brief_description: An animated film in which a young boy’s enquiries about money lead to a lesson on the uses of a cheque book. During a visit to the bank the role of the manager, and other bank services are explained.

results.title: Hoverport
results.creator_credit: Stanley Goulder, Robert Kruger and National Coal Board
results.brief_description: The building of Britain’s first international port for hovercraft at Pegwell Bay near Ramsgate, on reclaimed land at the water’s edge. Shows the stages of reclamation and construction through adverse conditions in winter, and finally the hovercraft taking off for a brisk 70 mph run across the English channel to Calais.

results.title: Houses in the town
results.brief_description: Analyses the problems and practices of architects responsible for the design of new towns and “neighbourhoods” in Britain. A lecturer on town and country planning discusses the problem of density, illustrated by views of old, over-crowded tenements and newer, insufficiently compact buildings. An architect suggests how houses may be designed to conform to the character of the environment, how variety may be obtained in shapes, and useful and aesthetically pleasing spaces created. His points are made with the aid of models and actual scenes.

results.title: Houses in history
results.creator_credit: H.M. Nieter, Paul Rotha and Seven-League Unit
results.brief_description: The different kinds of material used for building in the British Isles and their influence on construction are studied, with a brief survey of the development of houses in England from the 13th century until today.

results.title: The Housefly and its control
results.brief_description: Describes the anatomy and reproductive cycle of the fly and outlines the steps that can be taken in the city and on the land to control its numbers.

results.title: The House-fly
results.brief_description: The life cycle of this common but extremely dangerous house-hold pest is presented in detail; the egg, larvae, pupa and adult fly are illustrated; a vivid illustration of how dangerous the fly is as a carrier of disease germs is given. The most satisfactory methods of getting rid of flies are shown, with emphasis being laid on the fact that community effort is much more effective than isolated individual attempts to get rid of flies.
